review_title: Hochwertiger Lampenhalter mit leichten Schwächen im Detail für den Dauereinsatz
reviews:
Lieferumfang:
2x Lampehalter
1x Batteriefach, leider nicht für 18650 verwendbar
1x horizontales Spannband
1x vertikales Überkopfspannband

Ich benutze das Kopfband seit über einem Monat jeden Tag auf dem Arbeitsweg und der Baustelle ca. 10-14 Stunden am Tag in Verbindung mit meiner Fenix UC35(etwas über 100g mit 18650er 3500 mAh Accu).

Spannband: 5/5

Alles ist sauber verarbeitet, keine Fransen, lohsen Nähte oder überstehendes Material. Spannung hat sich bisher nicht verändert, was nach über einem Monat ein gutes Zeichen ist. Auch Gipsstaub oder Nässe übersteht das Material ohne Probleme. Stirnband könnte man noch etwas stärker und breiter machen, da es blank auf dem Kopf nach einiger Zeit, zumindest mit einer größeren/schweren Lampe wie ich sie nutze, unangenehm wird. Mit Helm\Basecap, so wie ich es den ganzen Tag verwende und etwas Eingewöhnungszeit kann man ihn ermüdungsfrei den ganzen Tag nutzen.

Halterungen 5/5

Lampenhalter läst sich im Winkel über ein Drehgelenk einstellen. Er arretiert in ca. 15 Grad Schritten und rasted sauber ein. Die Lampe selbst wird mit einer Klammer, welche innen gummiert ist für besseren Halt, gehalten. Schraube, Gewindeeinsatz und Stift auf der Gegenseite sind aus Metall und weisen kein Spiel oder Mangel in der Verarbeitung auf.

Das Spannband\Halterung hält die Lampe sicher am Kopf, auch bei starken Kopfbewegungen, anstoßen des Kopfes an Decken, jeglicher Kopfneigung oder gar Sprüngen aus 3m höhe(vom Gerüst). Auch der eingestellte Neigungswinkel verstellt sich bei keiner dieser Fälle.

Schmutz oder Feuchtigkeit sind auch kein Problem.

Verbessungsvorschlag:
- den Clip zum fixieren der Länge des Spannbandes mit einer Schnalle versehen, welches verstellen des Spannbandes beim ab/aufsetzen(wenn man sich den Schweiß von der Stirn wischt) oder Stößten gegen die Lampe beim arbeiten auf engen Raum verhindert, ansonsten hält der Platikclip das Spannband sicher auf der eingestellten Länge
- einen der beiden Lampenhalter innen gummieren oder mit Schaumstoff für mehr Tragekopfort versehen
- der 2. Lampenhalter im Set sollte eine längere horizontale Schlaufenführung haben und leicht gewölbt sein, um straffer am Helm\Basecap zu sitzen welches gelgendliches wackeln der Lampe bei schnelleren Schwenkbewgungen mit dem Kopf oder Schwingungen des ganzen Körpers beim Kernlochbohren ohne Halterung reduzieren würde
- eine extra Clip ohne Lampen oder Batteriehalter um das Überkopfband zu verbinden, welches sich leider nur in Verbindung mit Batterihalter oder 2. Lampenhalter im Set verwenden läst, was auf engen Raum wie bei arbeiten in Zwischenwänden störend ist

Gewichtsverteilung mit schwerer Lampe ist etwas Gewöhnungssache und sicher störend für Leute die es nur selten und kurz verwenden. Auch die längere Verwendung ohne Helm\Basecap könnte besser sein, da der Lampenhalter nicht innen gummiert/gepolstert ist. Ein straff eingestelltes Band und der Lampenhalter werden nach kurzer Zeit unangenehm durch den Druck auf den Kopf ohne Kopfbedeckung. Alles in allem eine brauchbare Lösung für Leute die nach etwas Suchen auf was man sich blind Verlassen kann wenn man den halben Tag im dunkeln arbeiten muss, robust, solide verarbeitet und gut durchdacht mit leichten Schwächen wenn es darum geht die Lampe gegen Schwingungen des ganzen Körpers besser zu stabilisieren.

Wenn man nach einem Stirnband für den gelgendlichen Einsatz ohne Kopfbedeckung sucht, wird man mit einem besser gepolsterten Produkt sicher glücklicher.

review_title: Makes my Fenix torches even better
reviews: So I've only had this for a few days so far, but my experience with it has been very positive. I have a Fenix LD22 and a LD15. The LD22 is within specs to fit, the LD15 is too small. So first let me say I got this because I didn't really like any of the pure head lamps on the market and I wanted to be able to use my Feinx torches hands free at times. Specifically my tiny LD15. My LD22 fits perfect, nice tight grip, but it does feel a little heavy. Not enough to deter me from using it as needed though. One feature that bugs me a bit though, you can't pre-adjust the band size when off your head. It requires the band to be under tension, so on your head. Once you put it on, it is very quick and easy to adjust though, either making it tighter or looser as needed, and I haven't had any issues with it loosening on its own yet. So for those of you with smaller lights like my LD15, I have a work around. I just cut a small piece of a grippy jar opener and wrapped it around my LD15. It is grippy on both sides, so no issues with it coming out, and just enough extra diameter to be a very snug fit. It has worked perfect. The LD15 does get very hot when using on high mode normally, so I don't know if having it in a confined space like this will make any difference, but we'll see. review_title: How to use a light with a bigger diameter.
reviews:
Mine was delivered yesterday and none of my lights that use an 18650 battery or 2-123A lithium batteries would fit, until now. I placed my Zebra Light SC600 in the holder with the hinge facing down and removed the hold down screw. I then inserted a 8 inch long wire tie, Amazon sells them, search electrical cable ties, through the hole that the mounting screw normally is inserted. Then I continued placing the wire tie through the other openings in the bracket until I put the end of the wire tie into it's own end, which secures it. Wire ties/cable ties come in handy for many uses. Any hardware store or electrical supply store has them. If they are too short, just connect 2 or more together and cut the excess off. If you want to remove the light you will need to cut the wire tie off and put a new one on. Just about any 1 inch diameter or slightly bigger flashlight will fit with this method. I emailed Fenix for a recommendation for a 18650 flashlight to use and they responded with this: "If you want to use 18650 battery, the best light for you will be Fenix PD35 - http://www.fenixtactical.com/fenix-pd35.html

reviews:
I'm an enthusiast about flashlights and coolers. This includes an interest in headlamps. This is a review of the Fenix Headband for 18-22mm Flashlights. I try to explain in detail what qualities I take into consideration so readers can understand my reasoning behind the rating I give. However, if you want the short of it, skip to the conclusion.

There are several things that I look for when considering a flashlight. 1) Only flashlights that use AA or AAA batteries are considered. Those two batteries are the cheapest and most readily available batteries. Plus, in an emergency, I do not want to be scrambling for different types of batteries (C, D, 9V, CR123, or any other type of specialized battery). 2) The design has to be shock resistant and waterproof. 3) The longest battery life in proportion to the output. I would like an efficient flashlight. 4) Best combination of durability in ratio to size and weight. I look for the lightest and most compact lights that are durable, which is extremely important in headlamps.

I found that the Fenix LD20 met those standards exceptionally well and rated the flashlight a 5.0 out of 5.0 in a previous review. I soon began looking for a headlamp that had similar power.

The best headlamp I have is the Princeton Tec EOS, which was purchased over three years ago and has a maximum output of 50 lumens. I spent hours online and at the store to compare all the different headlamps for the best in consideration to durability, lightweight, batteries, output, efficiency, and comfort. When I purchased the Fenix LD20 earlier this year, the output easily outshone the other lights. Ever since then, I have been in search for headlamps that utilizes the CREE LED technology. Unfortunately, the headlamps with using CREE LED technology and having output close to 180 lumens took four AA batteries or specialized lithium cells. Either way, this left me with either a heavy set up or having to add specialized batteries to my stock of AA and AAA's. Fortunately, I found the Fenix Headband that utilizes my favorite flashlight, the Fenix LD20.

Positives: 1) The headband is as comfortable as the headband of the Princeton Tec EOS, which I considered to be the most comfortable band in my experience. The Fenix Headband can be set up with just the single, circular band around the head or with a second band connected to go over the top of the head. It was more comfortable for me to use just the single band around the head. 2) The Fenix Headband is fully adjustable. You can adjust the size around the head easily, the second band over the head, the position of the light mounts, and the position of the battery pack. 3) It comes with two flashlight mounts and a waterproof battery pack. The mounts have a rubberized interior so it can grip flashlights securely with out slips or scratches, and can rotate 360 degrees so light can be angled in any direction with distinct and locking incremental clicks. This also means you can set up a flashlight on each side of your head with different angles and directions for each light. 4) Everything appears to be of excellent quality. 5) When using the LD20, the Fenix Headband makes an extremely powerful and efficient headlamp.

Negatives: 1) One picky thing is that the Fenix Headband when set up with the LD20 is heavier than the Princeton Tec EOS. However, the power and efficiency of the LD20's output far outweighs the amount of weight added. If the Fenix Headband were any less comfortable, this would be a significant issue. I remain hopeful that Fenix will focus on a lightweight headlamp that uses the powerful and efficient CREE technology.

Conclusion: Overall, the Fenix Headband is a fully adjustable high quality accessory with excellent build quality, top-level comfort, and allows flashlights such as the Fenix LD20 (with a diameter of 18-22mm) to be used hands-free in the form of a headlamp. I would rate the Fenix Headband a 5.0 out of 5.0. My only wish is that the set-up could be more lightweight. However, this is not a problem of the Fenix Headband, but a result of using regular flashlights as headlamps.

review_title: I'm even more impressed with Fenix
reviews:
I never write reviews but I have to give credit where credit is due. Fenix is a great company that builds quality products. I bought the LD-20 a few months ago and it's by far the best flashlight I've ever purchased. One is normal sized while the other is about half that size and can fit around your forearm/leg/wrist/whatever. It comes with two mounting clips. It comes with a battery mounting clip with two capsules on it that carries two backup AA batteries (has watertight seals on it). It also comes with additional screws and o-rings. That was much more than I was expecting. Aside from all the extras they give you, the headband works great. It's as comfortable as just about any headlight. The clip that mounts your flashlight has a knurled surface so your flashlight wont move around at all, actually, you barely have to tighten it to make the flashlight immovable. The clip can rotate 360 degrees. My LD-20 fits perfectly. It's comfortable and is super handy.

TL;DR - Fenix is a damn good company that makes quality products. There are tons of extras with this headband and I'm very impressed. Never have I been disappointed with this company or its products.

review_title: I cannot recommend this headband for use with the LD20/22
reviews:
I cannot recommend this headband for use with the LD20/22. I'm not saying the headband itself is bad, but I'll explain.

For use with the Fenix LD line it has the perfect setup, decently long clamp to (in theory) balance the flashlight, and extra batteries right there if you ever happen to need them. Sounds great right? Well not so much

1. The LD's don't have a great balance in the first place, it's pretty rear heavy, and you may find yourself illuminating the night sky without constant adjustment. Yes, technically, you can mount it, but the flashlight's length and weight prevent it from being practical.,

2. The extra battery compartments are ridiculous looking, noisy, not easily accessed, and heavy!! The instant I put the whole rig on I felt foolish. The battery tubes are much too large for the AA batteries the LD20-22 requires, and any movement leaves a clacking noise on your temple (original mounting point). I felt like I had strapped an overweight maraca to the side of my head.

3. You don't need it! The most basic headlamps are going to take care of all of your dusk to dawn outdoor needs! Your eyes adjust to the light around you. Plus everyone you're camping with will hate you when you look at them...

Conclusion- nobody mounts high powered flashlights to their head unless they're mining or spelunking. You'll be fine with a cheapo head-mount for getting around the terrain, and a good pocket flashlight like this ---> Fenix Flashlights LD22 2015 Edition 300 Lumen LED Flashlight
